user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of reply_with_main_page:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_main_page (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  static const char page_content[] = MAIN_PAGE;
  static const size_t page_content_len =
    (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
  struct MHD_Response *resp;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len, page_content)
  ;
  if (NULL == resp)
    return MHD_NO;

  /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
     without this header. */
  (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE,
                                  "text/html");

  ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_OK, resp);
  MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len, page_content)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation if the MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static prototype accepts a const-qualified pointer (e.g. const void *buffer). In the shown code page_content is declared as static const char[], so passing it to a function that takes const void * preserves the const-qualification and satisfies MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Note: if the actual prototype of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static were to take a non-const pointer (e.g. void *buffer), then this call would discard the const qualifier and would violate Rule 8.13.
